body: cc @ssanderson
Ooh, shiny!  I'll try this out tonight.
@jreback Nice! I will try to go through it one of the coming days

@jreback one quirk I'm noticing is that if you construct a DataFrame directly from a DatetimeIndex, you lose the tz information:

```
In [1]: dates = date_range('2014-01-01', periods=10, tz='UTC')

In [2]: from_dict = DataFrame({'a': dates})

In [3]: from_dict.dtypes
Out[3]:
a    datetime64[ns, UTC]
dtype: object

In [4]: from_index = DataFrame(dates)

In [5]: from_index.dtypes
Out[5]:
0    datetime64[ns]
dtype: object
```

Is this expected behavior?

do you have the current one?

this all works (it might not have in a prior one)

This is the latest https://github.com/jreback/pandas/commit/19ec61d3bcbe84dada3f38bad3daa061a78707af I think

```
In [3]: from_dict
Out[3]: 
           a
0 2014-01-01
1 2014-01-02
2 2014-01-03
3 2014-01-04
4 2014-01-05
5 2014-01-06
6 2014-01-07
7 2014-01-08
8 2014-01-09
9 2014-01-10

In [4]: from_dict.dtypes
Out[4]: 
a    datetime64[ns, UTC]
dtype: object
```

`Series.values` IS a `DatetimeIndex` that is how its implemented. Its very similar to how `Sparse/Categorical` are done. This preserves the tz info inside the object (actually have freq too). Rather than relying upon a ndarray impl and passing it around. Much cleaner this way.

ok, indexing is fixed. wasn't testing things fully :mask:

> if you have a chance I'd like to see how you are actually using it, if you could post some small sample code would be great. I can time things, but having a usecase is even better.

@jreback here's a slightly modified version of some code that's part of a recent [Zipline](https://github.com/quantopian/zipline) change where I'm computing a matrix of dates/security_ids where I want to know, for each (date, security) pair, whether the security existed on that date.  I'm currently using numpy recarrays of int64 for this because doing it with series would probably be too slow.

```
def lifetimes_matrix(dates):
    """
    Compute a DataFrame representing asset lifetimes for the specified date
    range.

    Parameters
    ----------
    dates : pd.DatetimeIndex
        The dates for which to compute lifetimes.

    Returns
    -------
    lifetimes : pd.DataFrame
        A frame of dtype bool with `dates` as index and an Int64Index of
        assets as columns.  The value at `lifetimes.loc[date, asset]` will
        be True iff `asset` existed on `data`.
    """
    lifetimes = np.recarray(
        shape=(len(),),
        dtype=[('sid', 'i8'), ('start', 'i8'), ('end', 'i8')],
    )
    # Fill in lifetimes with values from database...

    raw_dates = dates.asi8[:, None]
    mask = (lifetimes.start <= raw_dates) & (raw_dates <= lifetimes.end)
    return pd.DataFrame(mask, index=dates, columns=lifetimes.sid)
```

This is by no means unreasonable for me to do, but I suspect that lots of people who are comfortable with pandas wouldn't know that they should drop into numpy for something like this because of the overhead of doing all these comparisons when the inputs have dtype `object`.

I think @llllllllll has also run into performance issues using blaze with pandas and PostgreSQL because we store postgres data in columns of type TimestampWithTimezone, which causes blaze to do computations on DataFrames of dtype object after pulling data out of the DB.
@ssanderson ok, both of these should be 'blazing' fast now. (the postgresql might take a tiny bit more work as this is a change there).

Here's another 'issue'. csv's don't have enough information to reconstruct the tz's really at all. Well they can be done as fixed zones, but you rarely want that. So you have to know what you are going to. Have you thought about this?

```
In [7]: df = DataFrame({'A' : date_range('20130101',periods=3),
                                  'B' : date_range('20130101',periods=3,tz='US/Eastern'),
                                  'C' : date_range('20130101',periods=3,tz='CET')})

In [8]: df.iloc[1,1] = pd.NaT

In [9]: df.iloc[1,2] = pd.NaT

In [10]: df
Out[10]: 
           A                         B                         C
0 2013-01-01 2013-01-01 00:00:00-05:00 2013-01-01 00:00:00+01:00
1 2013-01-02                       NaT                       NaT
2 2013-01-03 2013-01-03 00:00:00-05:00 2013-01-03 00:00:00+01:00

In [11]: df.dtypes
Out[11]: 
A                datetime64[ns]
B    datetime64[ns, US/Eastern]
C           datetime64[ns, CET]
dtype: object

In [12]: df.to_csv('foo.csv')

In [13]: !cat foo.csv
,A,B,C
0,2013-01-01,2013-01-01 00:00:00-05:00,2013-01-01 00:00:00+01:00
1,2013-01-02,,
2,2013-01-03,2013-01-03 00:00:00-05:00,2013-01-03 00:00:00+01:00

In [14]: rdf = pd.read_csv('foo.csv',index_col=0)

In [15]: rdf
Out[15]: 
            A                          B                          C
0  2013-01-01  2013-01-01 00:00:00-05:00  2013-01-01 00:00:00+01:00
1  2013-01-02                        NaN                        NaN
2  2013-01-03  2013-01-03 00:00:00-05:00  2013-01-03 00:00:00+01:00

In [16]: rdf.dtypes
Out[16]: 
A    object
B    object
C    object
dtype: object

In [17]: pd.to_datetime(rdf['B']).dt.tz_localize('UTC').dt.tz_convert('US/Eastern')
Out[17]: 
0   2013-01-01 00:00:00-05:00
1                         NaT
2   2013-01-03 00:00:00-05:00
dtype: datetime64[ns, US/Eastern]
```

@ssanderson I didn't run into any issue with performance; however, I just chose to use tz-naiive datetimes throughout to avoid the penalties. The main issue was actually pushing things into postgress as type object because it would create a column with type string instead of datetime; however, this should fix all of that.

We have so many issues roundtripping csvs that had DatetimeIndex with timezones.  You have to write ugly things like stripping off the tz offset and then localize afterwards.  I think passing in the timezone name to `read_csv` and have that do the stripping/localizing would be an okay thing.

@rockg yes I agree. I think best to (before the PR and after) to simply read as object that do your own conversions. I suppose we could allow something like

`pd.read_csv(...., parse_dates= [{column : 'A', tz : 'US/Eastern'}]` (or accept this in the `dtype` spec). but that's another issue

@jorisvandenbossche https://travis-ci.org/jreback/pandas/jobs/69726572

can you repro this?

This works locally and therefore is puzzling.
I actually don't want it to coerce the object dtypes to my new format for SQL now (its tricky because of the funny postgres tz objects).
